Spring Reading Week Shorter
Under New School Calendar
by Catherine Raeff
The 1986 spring semester will
start on January 27, one week
later than its usual starting date
as a result of the extension of
the intersession period. According to Lucien Brush, former
dean of arts and sciences and
Registrar Robert Cyphers, open
period, which used to last one
week, has been shortened by
two days in order to compensate for the late start, while still
allowing for enough time between the end of exam week and
commencement.
"Intersession was the major
driving force in changing the
starting date of second
semester," said Cyphers. In the
past intersession has lasted
three or four weeks depending
on when New Year's Day falls.

This year, however, New Year's
Day is on a Wednesday, and according to the original 1985-86
academic calander, intersession
would have started on Thursday, January 2, and ended on
January 17, to allow for classes
to begin at the regular time.
This schedule made intersession "so small that it would not
be worth having," said Brush.
Therefore, the schedule was
revised with the decision to
delay the start of second
semester and reduce the open
week to reading days lasting
from May 8 until May 11.
While the name of the preexam period has been changed
"it will not preclude the faculty from using it" for summaries, review sessions or exams, Cyphers said. Consequently, the function of the

period is expected to stay the
same.
Martha Roseman, assistant
dean of academic studies, who
is responsible for processing
grades once the professors turn
them in, anticipates a "terrible
problem. The whole office
literally stops [to call] in for
said
grades,"
missing
Roseman. Because the time between the end of exam week and
commencement has been reduced, Roseman feels that it will be
more difficult this to clear
seniors for graduation. If
necessary, Roseman is considering the possibility of having to issue blank diplomas at
commencement, but she hopes
that such an action will not be
necessary.

Because of the minimal student participation in this area
and the availability of the Math
and Math Science major, the
committee reccommended that
the Quantitative Studies Area
Major be dropped. This suggestion was adopted as policy with
the beginning of the 1985 fall
term. This change, however,
does not affect those students
currently enrolled in the major.
The committee that studied
the Natural Science Area Major was composed of Lloyd
Armstrong, Maurice Bessman,
Hans Eugster, David Olton,
Douglas Poland (chairman),
and Martha Roseman. They
reviewed the present status of
the area major and compared it
to other standard science
majors.
In the past, according to
their report, the requirements
for the major were: 40 (N)
credits (including chemistry and
lab, physics,and lab, and 15
credits beyond the 300 level), 36
(H), (Q), or (S) credits, and
other unspecified courses to obtain a total of 120 credits. A
Natural Science Area Major is
often adopted by pre-meds,

says the report, because it permits them to fullfill all their
pre-med requirements (inorganic and organic chemistry,
their respective labs, MCB and
lab, physics and lab„ and
calculus.) Almost half(43 percent) of the students graduating
in the natural sciences receive
their Baccalaureate degree in
the Natural Science Area Major.
The report concluded that
the Natural Science Area Major lacks depth, consisting of
large, introductory classes with
only one required 300 level
course. The report characterized the major as a minimal
"Pre-med Major" for a larger
number of undergraduates.
However, the committee did
not wish to abandon the major
for two reasons. First, by forcing all students presently enrolled in the area major to adopt
a more traditional science, the
small, highly specialized,
upper-level science laboratories
would be swamped by the flux
of new students. Secondly,
eliminating the major would
not afford students the opportunity and flexibility to construct a program that spans two
traditional fields.

We Deserve a Break... Meets the West
For a Day?

by Scott Proestel

Two things need to be said about the
new Fall Break. The first is that it is
essentially meaningless. The second is
that it represents a major accomplishment for students.
The break is more or less unimportant
in that one day is hardly going to make
a dramatic difference in anyone's life. It
certainly will be nice, and even that one
day will relieve some of the infamous
fall-semester pressure; however, it will
most emphatically not change the way
students view the term. The fall will still
represent one long, monotonous block
of classes.
What is much more important is that,
entirely because of student action the
break has been established and
remarkably quickly.
It was only last winter, after all, that
the Student Council formed its Ad Hoc
Committee on Fall Break. After conduc-

ting a survey of Hopkins students and
of other colleges, the panel began lobbying the administration for such a
vacation.
Responding to those efforts, the administration decided to go ahead with a
fall break, and rearranged the calendar
accordingly this summer.
All of that ought to make any concerned student quite happy. Not only has the
administration listened to student concerns, but something far more unusual
has happened: Hopkins students have
gotten off their rumps and taken an active role in improving the university.
That just doesn't happen around here.
So although the break itself is nothing
to get too excited about, the way it came
about is truly remarkable. Maybe
students will actually start caring what
goes on around here.

One More Dean
Deans have been increasing around
here the last few years as fast as tuition.
Only four years ago, just one year
before the current senior class arrived,
there was one dean in charge of
Homewood. The following year two
deans were given joint command. And
now a triad of top-ranking people has
been created. Whether a three-headed
beast can run with any direction remains
to be seen.
It seems, intuitively, that there must
be one man at the top; someone must be
in charge. University President Steven
Muller is both unwilling and unable to
fill that post: unwilling in that he is
primarily interested in Hopkins' international aspects; unable in that his energy
must be largely devoted to the university's other divisions.
So until four years ago, George Owen,
dean of the Homewood faculties, was
responsible for handling campus affairs.
When he retired, control of the campus
was turned over to two deans: the Dean
of the School of Arts and Sciences and
the Dean of the G.W.C. Whiting School
of Engineering. That system lasted a couple years, even when one of the two head
deans changed.(Arts and Sciences chief
Sigmund Suskind resigned and was
replaced by George Fisher.) Last spring,
it was announced that a new top-ranking
position would be created: the Dean of
Administration. Robert Welch, the new
kid on the block this fall, was hired to
fill the slot.
When the new position was created,
it was said a third dean would allow
Fisher and Dean of the G.W.C. School
of Engineering V. David VandeLinde to
focus on academic concerns, while
avoiding administrative hassles.
But just how much the new system will

streamline administrative decisions is
unknown. Complaints have been frequent the last two years that no one
seemed in charge much of the time.
When a decision was needed, the two
deans would have to consult, often a
time-consuming process.
With the addition of yet another dean,
it seems natural that situation would only
worsen. Muller argues, however, that the
responsibilities of the three deans are sufficiently distinct to avoid a directionless
muddle at the top.
To at least a certain extent, that may
be true. Administrative concerns will
now have to be brought before only one
dean. On those issues at least, that could
mean a smoother operation.
But even on academic issues, where
Fisher and VandeLinde will continue
their joint rule, there may be an advantage to the new structure. As part of
Welch's hiring, the position of Associate
Dean of Undergraduate and Graduate
Studies was abolished. While some of
what Brush did will fall under Welch's
control, much will be handled by Fisher
and VandeLinde's deputies. Brush's
position within the administration had
become increasingly unclear, an the
abolition of what had become, in
Muller's words, a "redundant" position
should facilitate quick decisions on
academic matters.
Students ought to have a healthy skepticism about the new administrative
structure. At first glance, it appears to
worsen an already bad situation. But it
is also true that it provides an opportunity to improve how Homewood is run.
Only the next few months(and the first
few crises) will reveal if that opportunity has been seized.

You've seen it every
summer—for three months out
of the year, the East Coast
dresses like the West Coast.
Summer rolls in, and with it
comes the Ocean Pacific Principle. It states that although the
Atlantic is an ocean also, it
somehow doen't quite match
up to the Pacific. So people in
the East dress like they're in
California, and pretend that the
Pacific is fifty yards from their
condo.
Many clothes manufacturers
have made millions off of this
simple principle. Have you ever
seen Ocean Pacific's spring
line?(A rhetorical question.) It
actually looks a great deal like
their winter line. Whether it's
extra-long green baggies, or
extra-long pink baggies, their
Op logo is nearby. But you
don't have to take my word for
it—just look around. The
extra-large shirts with bright
lettering or surfers riding blue
waves are a sure giveaway.
I am a capitalist, and I think
it's great that clothing
manufacturers can make
money off of our fantasies. It
gives me a warm feeling inside
whenever I see "Surf Naked"
or "Life's a Beach" tee-shirts
that a company has churned
out. It isn't with them that I
have a problem. What really
annoys me is the sunglass craze
that tagged along with the
clothing fad.
I enjoy looking into people's
eyes. You can understand a lot
about a person by searching in
their eyes. You can tell how
their day has been, if something

is bothering them, or if they feel
like going out to eat. However,
with the advent of sunglasses,
this has all been changed. The
silent two-way communication
has been destroyed. Trying to
look into they eyes of someone
wearing sunglasses is like looking into a black abyss. Unless
of course they are wearing mirrored sunglasses—then you get
to look into your own eyes,
which is stupid because you
already know how you feel.
You only have to see a girl
bat her eyes once to realize that
eyes
are
a
powerful
aphrodisiac. But yet some people insist on covering up their
eyes with sunglasses anyway.
By far the worst offenders are
mirrored sunglasses. The girl
that you wanted to go out with
yesterday now looks like the
cockroach you killed last night.
There is one advantage to
wearing sunglasses. You may
not want people looking into
your eyes and understanding
how you feel. This form of
communication may be an annoyance to you. But, if that is
the case, you might as well dig
a hole now, and live (and die)
there.
In conclusion, I believe my
opinion is best expressed by an
ancient manuscript recently
discovered in Asia:
California,
Your girls may be great,
And your wine may be fine,
Your baggies are colorful,
But are no friends of mine,
Though there are things
the East may lack,
Please, CA, please, take
your sunglasses back.
—Kubla Khan

Descent into the Mainstream

A strange thing happened to
me over the summer—I started
running out of things to cornplain about. There was TV I
wanted to watch, I enjoyed the
movies I saw; hell the deans
even reduced my rent. Most
amazing (and disconcerting),
though, was the fact that there
were, for the first time in a
while, good pop songs on the
radio—Top 40-AM radio, no
less. Sting, the Eurythmics,
Katrina and the Waves—all
good stuff; I didn't even mind
Raspberry Beret that much I
was
getting
seriously
concerned—were things really
so good or was I going going. . . Mainstream?!
Imagine my relief then, when
I dropped by the News-Letter
office at the end of the summer
and found a stack of undistinguished RCA records just
asking for abuse. All of them
trying to capitalize on the latest
fad, all of them worthless excercises in uncreative corporate
greed, or so I thought... Truth
is, the albums I've listened to so
far haven't even been that ternble. Not extremely good
perhaps, but certainly,
tolerable. Damn. So just to
prove to myself that my tastes
haven't regressed completely,
I've reviewed a couple of
albums of my own choosing
which are decidedly less
mainstream.
Five Star: Luxury of Life
Of all the RCA albums, this
one had the most potential to
be truly exploitative: They're
black, they're all in the same
family, and there just happens
to be five of them. Sound
familiar? Add to that the fact
that the young boy in the band
looks a lot like a young Micheal
and the older looks a lot like the
older Micheal and well...there
you have it. It turns out,
though, that Five Star is already
quite popular in England. And

it appears as if soon they're going to have some American success too. They're at their best
when they play a gentle funk
evocative of New Edition, as on
"Love Take Over" and
"Let Me Be the One," but
they're
.at
their
old synth-pop cliches—the
ballady "Say Goodbye" or the
robotics of "System Addict."
in all, however, not a bad
effort.
Mr. Mister: Welcome to the
Real World. A hard-working
synth-band? Actually, the synthesizer having infiltrated even
the works of Mr. Springsteen,
"synth-band" has little meaning anymore. Even so, this
band is a great example of just
hciw entrenched the synth has
become in modern pop. This
album is all rather pleasant, the
synth having filled in all the
spaces and leaving it with a
rather fluffy consistency. Truly an album to fall asleep
to...My goodness, the lyrics,
though: "Time it passes much
too fast/and time I want to
make it last." Halfway through
I suffered a banality attack.
Shy: Brave the Storm. Admittedly the worst of the bunch but
still better than the heavy-metal
artwork would imply. They
sound more like Styx or REO
Speedwagon than Judas Priest.
They use synthesizers, too. And
the lead singer can sing real
high.
Rock and Roll—The Early
Days. The soundtrack to an upcoming video cassette and one
of the best oldies compilations
to date. "Rock Around the
Clock," "Blue Suede Shoes,"
"Bo Didley," "Tutti Frutti,"
"Great Balls of Fire," all by those
that made them famous
plus "Hound Dog" done by Big
Mama Thornton (which makes
a hell of a lot more sense when
sung by a woman)and more. If
you're not sick of all these
songs and don't own any of

these, this is a good place to get
them. A worthwhile release if
just to get all the oldie hits onto one album.

Horrible Truth About Burma.
(Ace of Hearts) The last possiL.t. —tp.nce hy Mission of Burma,
ma, arguabl one_ of the
greatest American bands of the
last decade. This is a compilation of live recordings made all
over the country during their
final tour a couple of years ago.
Unlike most live albums,
though, all the songs here are
previously unrecorded by
M.O.B. so this is equivalent to
a brand new album. The live
format doesn't hurt the album
in the least since the success of
Mission of Burma always lied
in their sheer intensity and not
in their clarity. As with a lot of
post-punk this is perhaps not

kind of "Folk Hardcore" but

not in the music but in the
lyrics. Prescott, who wrote
most of the songs on the album,
must have grown up on a
farm—songs likeCornfield,

Prescott (i.e. Mission of Burma) make this and extremely
original album. I doubt
anything like this has ever been
done before.

The Lover is a gem of a
book. Small, simple, and highly
polished, it succeeds at catching
light and giving a new elegance
to autobiography, blending it
smoothly with fiction until the
differences don't matter
anymore.
This is a foreign novel. Its
author, Marguerite Duras, is
one of France's oldest and most
celebrated authors, but remains
relatively unknown by this
country's popular reading audience. In The Lover, the
French feeling is everywhere;
the dreamlike, present-tense
writing, and the strong erotic
imagery. It seems to effortlessly avoid the crude explicitness
which dominates modern fiction, yet is highly charged. The
book is romantic in the best
sense of the word; it goes
beyond the couple to all the
people around them, their surroundings, their world.
The story's narrator is a
15-year-old French girl whose
widowed mother has settled in
Cambodia. The mother is a
strange, shabbily-dressed
school headmistress going
senile, her brothers are itinerant
good-for-nothings; the younger
one loves Duras but is weak,
the other delights in hearing her
beaten. These Europeans living
off the graces of Southeast Asia
have nothing glamourous about

them. There is no Jewel-in-theCrown colonialism, no sense of
grandeur.
The girl's family has lost its
money and lives in squalid
decay. While the family still has
an unpaid houseboy, it is "garbage" he serves them—"storks,
baby crocodiles." The heroine
dresses in silken rags, gold lame
evening shoes and a man's
fedora, desperate to be different and make something
beautiful out of the chaos.
During the school year, the
heroine sleeps at a state-run
boarding school and attends
classes at her mother's French
high school. As one of two
white pupils at the boarding
school, she is allowed complete
freedom to come and go at
night. She does this with daily
frequency once she accepts a
ride from "the lover," who remains nameless throughout the
whole book.
They meet symbolically, as
the girl is crossing the water
from her mother's shack to the
school in Saigon. There is a
river of difference separating
the Asians from the whites—a
vastness far too horrifying for
either society to even talk
about.
The lover is close to thirty,
Chinese, Paris-educated, and
wealthy. He lounges beside his
chauffered black limousine
watching the girl for days. She
initially takes a ride with him
for his wealth, and tells him this
quite candidly after their first
love-making session. This hardness, this lack of sentimentali-

ty and feeling makes him mad
for her. And she falls in love
with the feel, the aura of
passion.
There are long, hot afternoons in his apartment in
Saigon. There are longer, stultifying evenings when he takes
her family to elegant Chinese
restaurants and nightclubs.
They do not speak to him; they
cannot comprehend his stature
as a person, let alone the
daughter's lover. Yet they eat
his food and drink his wine,
later beating the girl who cries
over and over that they are not
lovers, they are just friends.
This issue of racism is handled gracefully by the author.
While Duras' family considers
the lover a horrifying disgrace,
poverty binds them to him.
While the girl's whiteness gives
her power over the lover, he can
never marry her. To the lover's
powerful, landowner father,
Duras is just "the little white
whore from Sadec." In the end
it is Duras, the object of desire,
who is the true pariah. Rejected
by her .schoolfriends, family,
the Chinese and Cambodians,
she addresses a bleak destiny
alone.

by Scott Proestel

Two things need to be said about the
new Fall Break. The first is that it is
essentially meaningless. The second is
that it represents a major accomplishment for students.
The break is more or less unimportant
in that one day is hardly going to make
a dramatic difference in anyone's life. It
certainly will be nice, and even that one
day will relieve some of the infamous
fall-semester pressure; however, it will
most emphatically not change the way
students view the term. The fall will still
represent one long, monotonous block
of classes.
What is much more important is that,
entirely because of student action the
break has been established and
remarkably quickly.
It was only last winter, after all, that
the Student Council formed its Ad Hoc
Committee on Fall Break. After conduc-

ting a survey of Hopkins students and
of other colleges, the panel began lobbying the administration for such a
vacation.
Responding to those efforts, the administration decided to go ahead with a
fall break, and rearranged the calendar
accordingly this summer.
All of that ought to make any concerned student quite happy. Not only has the
administration listened to student concerns, but something far more unusual
has happened: Hopkins students have
gotten off their rumps and taken an active role in improving the university.
That just doesn't happen around here.
So although the break itself is nothing
to get too excited about, the way it came
about is truly remarkable. Maybe
students will actually start caring what
goes on around here.

One More Dean
Deans have been increasing around
here the last few years as fast as tuition.
Only four years ago, just one year
before the current senior class arrived,
there was one dean in charge of
Homewood. The following year two
deans were given joint command. And
now a triad of top-ranking people has
been created. Whether a three-headed
beast can run with any direction remains
to be seen.
It seems, intuitively, that there must
be one man at the top; someone must be
in charge. University President Steven
Muller is both unwilling and unable to
fill that post: unwilling in that he is
primarily interested in Hopkins' international aspects; unable in that his energy
must be largely devoted to the university's other divisions.
So until four years ago, George Owen,
dean of the Homewood faculties, was
responsible for handling campus affairs.
When he retired, control of the campus
was turned over to two deans: the Dean
of the School of Arts and Sciences and
the Dean of the G.W.C. Whiting School
of Engineering. That system lasted a couple years, even when one of the two head
deans changed.(Arts and Sciences chief
Sigmund Suskind resigned and was
replaced by George Fisher.) Last spring,
it was announced that a new top-ranking
position would be created: the Dean of
Administration. Robert Welch, the new
kid on the block this fall, was hired to
fill the slot.
When the new position was created,
it was said a third dean would allow
Fisher and Dean of the G.W.C. School
of Engineering V. David VandeLinde to
focus on academic concerns, while
avoiding administrative hassles.
But just how much the new system will

streamline administrative decisions is
unknown. Complaints have been frequent the last two years that no one
seemed in charge much of the time.
When a decision was needed, the two
deans would have to consult, often a
time-consuming process.
With the addition of yet another dean,
it seems natural that situation would only
worsen. Muller argues, however, that the
responsibilities of the three deans are sufficiently distinct to avoid a directionless
muddle at the top.
To at least a certain extent, that may
be true. Administrative concerns will
now have to be brought before only one
dean. On those issues at least, that could
mean a smoother operation.
But even on academic issues, where
Fisher and VandeLinde will continue
their joint rule, there may be an advantage to the new structure. As part of
Welch's hiring, the position of Associate
Dean of Undergraduate and Graduate
Studies was abolished. While some of
what Brush did will fall under Welch's
control, much will be handled by Fisher
and VandeLinde's deputies. Brush's
position within the administration had
become increasingly unclear, an the
abolition of what had become, in
Muller's words, a "redundant" position
should facilitate quick decisions on
academic matters.
Students ought to have a healthy skepticism about the new administrative
structure. At first glance, it appears to
worsen an already bad situation. But it
is also true that it provides an opportunity to improve how Homewood is run.
Only the next few months(and the first
few crises) will reveal if that opportunity has been seized.

You've seen it every
summer—for three months out
of the year, the East Coast
dresses like the West Coast.
Summer rolls in, and with it
comes the Ocean Pacific Principle. It states that although the
Atlantic is an ocean also, it
somehow doen't quite match
up to the Pacific. So people in
the East dress like they're in
California, and pretend that the
Pacific is fifty yards from their
condo.
Many clothes manufacturers
have made millions off of this
simple principle. Have you ever
seen Ocean Pacific's spring
line?(A rhetorical question.) It
actually looks a great deal like
their winter line. Whether it's
extra-long green baggies, or
extra-long pink baggies, their
Op logo is nearby. But you
don't have to take my word for
it—just look around. The
extra-large shirts with bright
lettering or surfers riding blue
waves are a sure giveaway.
I am a capitalist, and I think
it's great that clothing
manufacturers can make
money off of our fantasies. It
gives me a warm feeling inside
whenever I see "Surf Naked"
or "Life's a Beach" tee-shirts
that a company has churned
out. It isn't with them that I
have a problem. What really
annoys me is the sunglass craze
that tagged along with the
clothing fad.
I enjoy looking into people's
eyes. You can understand a lot
about a person by searching in
their eyes. You can tell how
their day has been, if something

is bothering them, or if they feel
like going out to eat. However,
with the advent of sunglasses,
this has all been changed. The
silent two-way communication
has been destroyed. Trying to
look into they eyes of someone
wearing sunglasses is like looking into a black abyss. Unless
of course they are wearing mirrored sunglasses—then you get
to look into your own eyes,
which is stupid because you
already know how you feel.
You only have to see a girl
bat her eyes once to realize that
eyes
are
a
powerful
aphrodisiac. But yet some people insist on covering up their
eyes with sunglasses anyway.
By far the worst offenders are
mirrored sunglasses. The girl
that you wanted to go out with
yesterday now looks like the
cockroach you killed last night.
There is one advantage to
wearing sunglasses. You may
not want people looking into
your eyes and understanding
how you feel. This form of
communication may be an annoyance to you. But, if that is
the case, you might as well dig
a hole now, and live (and die)
there.
In conclusion, I believe my
opinion is best expressed by an
ancient manuscript recently
discovered in Asia:
California,
Your girls may be great,
And your wine may be fine,
Your baggies are colorful,
But are no friends of mine,
Though there are things
the East may lack,
Please, CA, please, take
your sunglasses back.
—Kubla Khan

prove to myself that my tastes

albums of my own choosing
which are decidedly less
mainstream.

Of all the RCA albums, this
one had the most potential to
be truly exploitative: They're
black, they're all in the same

familiar? Add to that the fact
that the young boy in the band
looks a lot like a young Micheal
and the older looks a lot like the
older Micheal and well...there
you have it. It turns out,
though, that Five Star is already
quite popular in England. And

evocative of New Edition, as on

.at

in all, however, not a bad
effort.

synth-band? Actually, the synthesizer having infiltrated even

The Lover is a gem of a
book. Small, simple, and highly
polished, it succeeds at catching
light and giving a new elegance
to autobiography, blending it
smoothly with fiction until the
differences don't matter
anymore.
This is a foreign novel. Its
author, Marguerite Duras, is
one of France's oldest and most
celebrated authors, but remains
relatively unknown by this
country's popular reading audience. In The Lover, the
French feeling is everywhere;
the dreamlike, present-tense
writing, and the strong erotic
imagery. It seems to effortlessly avoid the crude explicitness
which dominates modern fiction, yet is highly charged. The
book is romantic in the best
sense of the word; it goes
beyond the couple to all the
people around them, their surroundings, their world.
The story's narrator is a
15-year-old French girl whose
widowed mother has settled in
Cambodia. The mother is a
strange, shabbily-dressed
school headmistress going
senile, her brothers are itinerant
good-for-nothings; the younger
one loves Duras but is weak,
the other delights in hearing her
beaten. These Europeans living
off the graces of Southeast Asia
have nothing glamourous about

them. There is no Jewel-in-theCrown colonialism, no sense of
grandeur.
The girl's family has lost its
money and lives in squalid
decay. While the family still has
an unpaid houseboy, it is "garbage" he serves them—"storks,
baby crocodiles." The heroine
dresses in silken rags, gold lame
evening shoes and a man's
fedora, desperate to be different and make something
beautiful out of the chaos.
During the school year, the
heroine sleeps at a state-run
boarding school and attends
classes at her mother's French
high school. As one of two
white pupils at the boarding
school, she is allowed complete
freedom to come and go at
night. She does this with daily
frequency once she accepts a
ride from "the lover," who remains nameless throughout the
whole book.
They meet symbolically, as
the girl is crossing the water
from her mother's shack to the
school in Saigon. There is a
river of difference separating
the Asians from the whites—a
vastness far too horrifying for
either society to even talk
about.
The lover is close to thirty,
Chinese, Paris-educated, and
wealthy. He lounges beside his
chauffered black limousine
watching the girl for days. She
initially takes a ride with him
for his wealth, and tells him this
quite candidly after their first
love-making session. This hardness, this lack of sentimentali-

ty and feeling makes him mad
for her. And she falls in love
with the feel, the aura of
passion.
There are long, hot afternoons in his apartment in
Saigon. There are longer, stultifying evenings when he takes
her family to elegant Chinese
restaurants and nightclubs.
They do not speak to him; they
cannot comprehend his stature
as a person, let alone the
daughter's lover. Yet they eat
his food and drink his wine,
later beating the girl who cries
over and over that they are not
lovers, they are just friends.
This issue of racism is handled gracefully by the author.
While Duras' family considers
the lover a horrifying disgrace,
poverty binds them to him.
While the girl's whiteness gives
her power over the lover, he can
never marry her. To the lover's
powerful, landowner father,
Duras is just "the little white
whore from Sadec." In the end
it is Duras, the object of desire,
who is the true pariah. Rejected
by her .schoolfriends, family,
the Chinese and Cambodians,
she addresses a bleak destiny
alone.
